Short-Term Distribution, Long-Term Absorption A Classic Cycle Signal for BTC$BTC    Recent on-chain data highlights a familiar dynamic between short-term holders (STHs) and long-term holders (LTHs) that often defines key phases of the #Bitcoin  cycle. The 30-day cumulative net position change shows STHs leaning toward distribution during periods of elevated price levels, while LTHs continue to absorb supply during pullbacks and consolidation phases. Historically, spikes in STH net outflows tend to align with short-term overheating, when momentum-driven participants take profit into strength. This behavior is once again visible as short-term cohorts reduce exposure after sharp advances, introducing near-term volatility but at the same time easing speculative excess in the market structure.   In contrast, the 30-day net position change of LTHs tells a structurally constructive story. Episodes of heavy selling pressure from STHs are being met with persistent accumulation from longer-term investors, a pattern that has repeatedly characterized   mid-cycle consolidations rather than macro tops. When BTC trades sideways after strong rallies and long-term holders continue to build positions, it usually reflects growing conviction in higher time-frame valuation and signals that supply is migrating from weaker hands to stronger ones.  Distribution by short-term participants creates the liquidity needed for long-term capital to scale in, while sustained LTH accumulation helps stabilize the market after explosive moves. As long as long-term holders do not shift into prolonged net distribution, the dominant trend remains intact, even if short-term price action stays choppy. In this context, the current divergence between short-term selling and long-term accumulation points less to a cycle peak and more to a continuation phase, keeping the medium-term outlook for BTC constructively biased despite inevitable volatility along the way.  #CryptoZeno  #BTC Price Analysis#

üá∫üá∏ California puts a 3-year clock on inactive crypto - what changes for $BTC  holders?  California has officially brought crypto under its Unclaimed Property Law with the passage of AB 1052. The rule is simple: 3 years of inactivity = asset considered abandoned.  This isn‚Äôt a forced liquidation model. Unlike other states, California must keep crypto in its native form, appointing a licensed custodian instead of selling coins into USD. That‚Äôs a key distinction - value is preserved, not crystallized at the moment of seizure.  Why this matters:  Crypto is now legally classified as intangible property  Long-term ‚Äúset it and forget it‚Äù custody is no longer neutral  Exchanges must implement notification systems before the 3-year clock expires  Self-custody quietly becomes the default for true HODL strategies  States like Illinois, Delaware, and Arizona already claim dormant crypto - but they liquidate first. California‚Äôs approach is more asset-protective, yet still forces action.  The timing is notable. This law arrives as $BTC  trades back above $90K, with broader market confidence rebuilding into 2026. Regulation here isn‚Äôt about banning crypto - it‚Äôs about forcing accountability in custody.  Bottom line: AB 1052 doesn‚Äôt kill HODL. It kills passive custody.
